revisions.*: Because "rvslots" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used.

{{Taxobox | image = Leucocoprinus fragillissimus 38188.jpg | image_caption = | image_width = 234px | regnum = [[Fungi]] | divisio = [[Basidiomycota]] | classis = [[Agaricomycetes]] | ordo = [[Agaricales]] | familia = [[Agaricaceae]] | genus = ''[[Leucocoprinus]]'' | species = '''''L. fragilissimus''''' | binomial = ''Leucocoprinus fragilissimus'' | binomial_authority = ([[Berk.]] & [[M.A.Curtis]]) [[Pat.]] (1900) | synonyms_ref = | synonyms = ''Hiatula fragilissima'' [[Henry William Ravenel|Ravenel]] (1853)
''Lepiota fragilissima'' (Ravenel) [[Andrew Price Morgan|Morgan]] (1907) }} {{mycomorphbox | name = ''Leucocoprinus fragilissimus'' | whichGills = free | capShape = campanulate | capShape2 = convex | hymeniumType=gills | stipeCharacter=ring | ecologicalType=saprotrophic | sporePrintColor=white | howEdible=unknown }} '''''Leucocoprinus fragilissimus''''', commonly known as the '''fragile dapperling''', is a [[species]] of [[gilled mushroom]] in the [[family (biology)|family]] [[Agaricaceae]]. ==Taxonomy== The species was first documented by French mycologist [[Narcisse Théophile Patouillard]] in 1900. ==Description== The [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] of the [[basidiocarp|fruit body]] is up to {{convert|4.5|cm|in|abbr=on}} wide, bell-shaped when young and growing to convex in maturity. It has a pale yellow colour that fades with age, and white [[lamella (mycology)|gills]]. The narrow [[stipe (mycology)|stalk]] is between 1 and 3 mm thick and very fragile.{{cite book|last1=Bessette|first1=Alan|last2=Bessette|first2=Arleen|title=Mushrooms of northeastern North America|publisher=Syracuse University Press|page=191|year=1997}} ===Similar species=== ''[[Leucocoprinus magnicystidiosus]]'' is a similar mushroom, with a darker disc and larger cheilocystidia. ==Habitat and distribution== Like all ''[[Leucocoprinus]]'' species, ''L. fragilissimus'' is a [[saprotroph]], living on very decayed plant matter ([[humus]] or compost). It grows solitarily or sparsely in wooded areas.{{cite web|url=http://www.mushroomthejournal.com/greatlakesdata/Taxa/Leucofragi1028.html#Main|title=Mushroom, the Journal of Wild Mushrooming|accessdate=28 March 2012}} The species is found in southern North America, South America, southern Europe, Africa, southern and eastern Asia, Australia, and New Zealand. ==Toxicity and chemistry== The toxicity of this mushroom is unknown. ==References== {{Reflist|refs= {{cite journal |author=Berkeley MJ, Curtis MA. |title=Centuries of North American fungi |journal=Annals and Magazine of Natural History |year=1853 |volume=12 |pages=417–35}} {{cite book |author=Patouillard N. |title=Essai taxonomique sur les familles et les genres des Hyménomycètes |year=1900 |publisher=Lucien Declume |location=Lons-Le-Saunier |page=171 |language=French |url=https://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/28232985}} {{cite book |author=Roberts P, Evans S. |title=The Book of Fungi |year=2011 |publisher=University of Chicago Press |location=Chicago, Illinois |page=214 |isbn=978-0226721170}} {{cite web |title=''Leucocoprinus fragilissimus'' (Berkeley & M.A. Curtis) Patouillard 1900 |url=http://www.mycobank.org/BioloMICS.aspx?Table=Mycobank&Rec=98288&Fields=All |publisher=[[MycoBank]]. International Mycological Association |accessdate=2012-03-31}} }} {{Taxonbar|from=Q4042819}} [[Category:Agaricaceae]] [[Category:Fungi described in 1853]] [[Category:Fungi of Africa]] [[Category:Fungi of Asia]] [[Category:Fungi of Australia]] [[Category:Fungi of New Zealand]] [[Category:Fungi of North America]] [[Category:Fungi of South America]] [[Category:Taxa named by Miles Joseph Berkeley]] {{Agaricaceae-stub}}
